comments:
This course provides students with an analytic framework for addressing how a corporation finances its activities and what investments it should make. Key aspects are the net-present-value approach to valuation and a portfolio approach to understanding risk. Topics include present-value techniques, valuation, the relationship between risk and return, capital market efficiency, the choice between equity and debt financing, and dividend policy.

This course combines mathematical examples with real-world examples of Corporate Finance concepts. Students agreed that “the course flow is easy to understand.” There are also helpful bi-weekly tutoring sessions. One student wished there were a “simple case study” to facilitate understanding of the material. Nevertheless, most students appreciated that the course covered “problems sufficiently.”

All students agree that Professor Grove is “excellent” and has a “very good command of the subject.” Students praised his ability to teach complex subject matter in a clear and concise way. They also appreciated how helpful Professor Grove was by providing additional tutoring.

Students recommend others to take this course with Professor Grove and agreed that it was a very enriching experience.
